content: The "Silver Alert Grant Program Act of 2008" aims to establish a grant program to improve State-administered notification systems for finding missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia-related illnesses. It also seeks to promote best practices for new and existing Silver Alert systems and increase awareness for coordinated efforts in locating missing individuals quickly. The Congress finds that Alzheimer's disease affects millions in the US, with a higher risk for older individuals. The aging population will lead to more cases in the future. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60% of patients will wander away from their care facilities. Alzheimer's disease increases the risk of wandering in patients, with over 60% likely to wander from care facilities. Some states have implemented notification systems to help locate missing individuals with dementia-related illnesses, improving chances of finding them. Other states have faced challenges in developing similar systems. Silver Alert systems aim to improve the chances of locating missing individuals with dementia-related illnesses. Congress emphasizes the need for clear criteria in issuing alerts to prevent frequent notifications and ensure alerts are only for those incapable of making personal decisions. Initiating a Silver Alert should involve someone who recently had contact with the missing individual. Other states have struggled with implementing similar systems due to budget constraints. Silver Alerts aim to locate missing individuals with dementia-related illnesses. Initiating an alert should involve someone who recently had contact with the missing individual, such as a legal guardian, family member, household resident, or caregiver. The process should prioritize privacy, dignity, and autonomy. Training for law enforcement on locating and communicating with individuals with dementia is encouraged, as well as coordination between agencies. The Federal Government can help States cover costs for Silver Alert systems to prevent harm to individuals with Alzheimer's and dementia. Coordination between State and local officials is crucial for effective communication and program administration. The Silver Alert System Grant Program is established under Section 4. The Attorney General can award grants to States to establish or improve Silver Alert systems. Grants are for one-year periods and must be at least $100,000. Regulations will be prescribed for eligibility and selection criteria. Authorization of $5,600,000 annually for fiscal years 2009-2013 to select States for grants under this section. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT ON SILVER ALERT SYSTEMS. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems, including a list of states with the system, number of alerts issued, successful locates, time taken to locate individuals, issuing agency, costs, criteria for alerts, and success rates in finding missing individuals. The Attorney General's annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes criteria for issuing alerts, actions taken by states to protect privacy and dignity of missing individuals, communication improvements between families and authorities, and any other relevant information determined by the Attorney General. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "Silver Alert system" refers to a State-administered notification system to locate missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The term "State" includes all states of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands.
